reviews.text: Stunning! Such a carefully restored old beauty and visiting transports you to another time. Myself and two friends arrived just in time for the guided tour and tickets are 16myr. Our guide was knowledgeable, had great anecdotes and was really funny. The house was a marvel and the stories about Cheong Fatt Tze and his family, the times they lived in, and how they built and lived in the house are a delight. The gift shop has lots of goodies and the bar is excellent. I had the best margaritas I've had in all Malaysia. A beautiful site all round!

I stayed here for two nights and I had a wonderful time. The place is beautiful and the breakfast was delicious. The price was affordable and I slept comfortably. My only issue was the WiFi wasn't good and I had to use my own data. I enjoyed being able to explore the house more than a regular person visiting the museum would be able to. There are certain out of bounds areas you can access as a guest. There's a hawker centre next to the mansion that serves delicious food too.

We were too poor to stay (sad) but we went on the tour (rm16) and stayed for a drink. The tour guide was knowledgeable and enthusiastic, willing to answer any questions. The house also has standalone exhibitions for those who couldn't make it for the tours (we went on the 11am one). Tours are all in English but other languages could be booked before hand.

Great guided tour which runs only a few sessions a day . It’s 16 ringgit for the tour.Lots of interesting history and culture behind the heritage. Amazing restoration of the building . The hotel rooms looks amazing and there is a happy hour for the bar after 5pm if you are keen for some alcoholic drinks . It’s worth to book the restaurants if you want to dine in there too as the food is delicious. The location is accessible by the local free cat bus which is just a few minutes walk from the car bus stop. The lobby of the house is also the mahjong scene from the movie “crazy rich Asian “

Disappointed with this tour. Had just toured Penang Mansion, which was excellent. On this tour, virtually nothing is seen. You walk from the entrance to the square in the middle. The history is interesting but if going to be mostly talking then should be comfortable and easy to hear. 
My advice is go later in afternoon and have a cocktail in bar. This was excellent and staff are wonderful.

10RM to get in. We enjoyed spending an hour or so here wandering round and learning about the history and architecture in the small museum. We also liked looking at where all the members went to university around the world and what they studied! We were pretty much the only people there so it's nice and calm, worth doing if you're strolling by.

As you approach Khoo Kongsi, you will be greeted by a breathtaking display of Chinese craftsmanship - intricate wood carvings and richly ornamented beams. Its hall is equally elaborate, beautifully decorated with lanterns and furnished with antique furniture. The grandest clan temple on the island, it was built by the forefathers of the Khoo family, who emigrated from South China. The building was so magnificent that upon its completion in 1989, the roof caught fire. Some believe it was due to its resemblance to the Emperor's palace in China.

Opening hours: 9.00am - 5.00pm
Entrance fee: rm10 adult & rm1 child

Quiet and calmer attraction. Not an essential thing to see in Georgetown, but you will not regret it if you come.

First walk through the info area to get an idea of what you're looking at when walking through the area and the historical significance of the complex. They've done a really good job explaining things on info signs. Learned a lot.

For me, this is one of artistic Asian building in Penang. It looks super pretty in real life. You can take lot of cool photos inside and outside the building. Quite small but 2 floors. Dont have any AC so it will little bit hot. I spent just 15-20 minutes before strolling around in George Town area. But still one of good spot!
Nice little streets to walk by and take in the surroundings. Days are really sunny and humid (march). One would be better off armed with hats, umbrellas and water.
Awesome!  A lot of info
Closed for renovation at the moment  - 25th dec 2018
This museum now close for renovation.
Conservation work in progress#thumbs up
Great experience

Not much to see here unless you love colonialism. Simply the remnants of the British colonialism. Penang doesn't excite me anymore. Near to the jetty. If you have been to the jetty, you can give this place a quick detour. Parking is a problem at busy times. You can visit some of the other places nearby if you have rented a car or have one of yours. Anyway, it is not in my list anymore and certainly I'm not visiting this place again on the next trip.
Vintage structure. Easy to find the location. Recommended

A very beautiful Clock Tower built with funds contributed a local philanthropist to commemorate Queen Victoria's 1897 Diamond Jubilee, the tower is sixty feet tall, one foot for each year of Victoria's reign.

Great spot for photography day or night, as its well lit.
Careful of the trafic in the roundabout getting a goid shot. Buses do make wide turns.
It's nice... But hard to take photos of because of the traffic

Since 1803, this historical place is a peaceful place with tranquility. You can see have a short walk around the temple and see Burmese architecture. The drink stall by Naing Oo is a great place to sit down n chill n talk to fellow travellers

Another historical landmark to visit on The island. Built by the Burmese people as inscribed on the entrance archway founded in 1803. The temple is located opposite the Thai Buddhist Wat Chaiyamangalaram in Pulau Tikus. This religious site  has its own unique niche unlike Thai temples, though both follows the direction of the Buddha. Here you find a large standing image of Buddha probably the height of a 4 storey high building as the main attraction draw. Other small images can be found inside the compound covering an area estimated about 3 acres. A pagoda like building sits on a large fish pond housing several deities, and the compound is literary filled with religious figurines or  landscape designs. Overall I find this place tranquil with calmness and a sense of peacefullness, as you wonder about undisturb with the freshing greenery. I have a wonderful time exploring every corner, there's plenty of Burmese blended cultural artwork drawn on walls. The place closes at 6.00 pm daily and entrace is free, donations are welcome.

A smaller buddist temple, but also providing a unique buddhist temple with very tall indoor standing buddha, along with about smaller (bigger than man) 12 statue buddha behind the tall standing budha. There are some chapel for private praying next door
Fantastic place to visit.  Just walk slowly round and absorb everything in.
Serene and tranquil. Look for the tortoises who are astonishing good at pretending to be statues. Darn things made me jump when they moved!

One of the oldest and famous temples in Penang island, also favourite for tourists especially during Chinese New Year, pray to seek good health, luck and fortune. For Taoist with young schooling children to pray to Confucius孔子 and Wénchāng gōng文昌公 (中 国有“北孔子、南文昌”之说) for guidance in their studies. After the prayer, walk across the street and you have the opportunity to experience the lively Little India for souvenirs, foods, herbs and spices. The surrounding is the famous Penang Heritage trail for you to explore further...the famous Khoo Kongsi enclave is just down the street about 400m away. Please go and explore...

Penang's most famous and oldest Taoist temple built by early Chinese immigrants nearly 3 centuries ago.
Its patron deity is Kuan Yin, also known as the Goddess of Mercy.
Following the temple's recent renovations, joss sticks are only allowed in the compound outside the building.  This is a welcome change as it makes the prayer hall less smoky & sooty.

Generations ago as a kid I used to worship here accompanying my parents in the early years. Those days the internal atmosphere in the temple would make devotees sob not because of sorrow  but rather from the smokey environment generated from burning joss sticks. I believe they, the temple management has forbid joss stick burning for some time now which is a good blessing.
Outside on the platz one still can see abundant pigeons disposing their pooh on the stone courtyard & buildings roof.

A temple that located in George Town Penang. This temple having crowded with the tourist when the Chinese New Year day. This temple also near from Kapitan Keling Mosque and easy to notice from the street. It makes this temple became on of the many tourism attractioin George Town, Penang

A Chinese temple with good atmosphere. Unfortunately it was too difficult for me to understand how to worship, but it is really a temple for local Chinese people, not for tourists 
.

Attended the service couple of times. Sunday they have two services: first one is at 8:30am and second one is at 10:30am. Service is for 90 minutes and it is only English. They use the pipe organ which is wonderful to listen to during the first service. I could see more people coming in for the first service compared to the second service.

They have giant screens so you don't have to look at the book for hymns/Bible reading. Choir can be better, suggest they get someone to play the pipe organ for the second service as well. Message was good. They do provide light snacks after both services.

Other than it being a 200 year old church, the architecture is plain and simple, long pillars, and white colored paint all over. Part of the church was bombed during WW2 and since then they didn't have the pipe organ. Only recently have they fixed it for their 200 years celebration. 

Plenty of parking space available and they have a small heritage center as well.

We've been here, even though we only see from the outside. Unfortunately there is no misa in the church, maybe we are allowed to watch it.

The building is cool, maintained very well with the age of the building that has been hundreds of years. Salute to the Penang government & church administrators.
Kind of cool if you like old Anglican Churches, but unless you are, I wouldn't go out of my way to see it.  If  you're in the neighborhood anyway, might as well go by. We couldn't go inside.

This Anglican church, built 200 years ago, is well-maintained & surrounded by greenery. Listed as one of the country's 50 national treasures, the St George's church underwent  a major restoration in 2009.
Its picturesque setting provides a perfect backdrop for photos, especially for couples marrying at the church.

Big church building even on big piece of land.  Location is also on a prime land. The field is green and huge area. What is so special of this big white church building is... its 199 years old. Yes its going 200 years in 2019. Wow.

A very spiritual place with a huge reclining Buddha. The place is of Thai religion and well respected. You have to take off your shoe or slipper at the entrance to enter. 

Inside you are able to walk around to pray and look at the history. Nice place to be.

One of the island's main tourist attractions with a giant Sleeping Buddha spanning the width of the temple. The entrance is "guarded" by two beautiful dragons in glass & mosaic.
Best to visit on a weekday as the place is packed with tourists during weekends.

Nice Buddhist Temple with intricate glass mozaic on some statues. Not as large in size, yet in a nice location close to Gurney Drive, there's another temple you can visit right across the road (literally like 20 steps away), that one has turtles at the back and some statues, no one harrasses you at both these temples, all very low key and relaxed, try to be as decently dressed as you can, enjoy!

Thai style Buddhist temple, with a huge reclining Buddha inside. I heard that this is 1 of the largest reclining statue in the world.
Within the temple, you can buy “Gold leaf” to paste onto some of the statues inside the temple ground (not all can be pasted)
A bottle of spray water is located next to the statues, it’s for u to spray so that u can apply the gold leaf easily.

Remember to respect holy ground u’re in. ◡̈
One of the Best Buddha Statue. Well maintained. Free entrance.

A great spot to runaway from the city & enjoy the ocean view. There are many clan jetties here. Each has its own beauty. Be sure to explore them all. 

From the entrance, you need to walk along the way between the houses. These houses also sell varieties of goods such as food, drinks, souvenir & many more.

The Clan Jetties have been around for just over 100 years. They are definitely worth the visit. The jetty itself goes out into the sea and has a little Chinese temple at the end ND good photo opportunity. There are also little shops along the way perfect place to live up little souvenirs

A very beautiful and historic place to be and to see. Every jetty belongs to another clan which makes every Jetty unique. I recommend the "folklore by the sea " theatre at the end of the chew jetty. A must see.

Fairly average compared to the very enjoyable hunt for the varied and talented street art sprinkled around Georgetown. Perhaps worth a visit if you have nothing else to do (and containing some street art itself), but I wouldn't rush.
I love this place so much, everything was great here, you have to come. You can buy some souvenirs and it's cheap. Big bowl ramen here smells really good but it contain pork i guess
Ein denkwürdiger  Ort

Nice garden full of different flora and fauna just next to tropical forest. It has some few tracks which lead to Penang hill top. Locals love to exercise here in Dawn and dusk. If you have time, make some time and join some of the taichi or Zumba classes. The garden also has an interesting lotus pond. If in season the flowers blooming scene is not to be missed.

Nice Scenery and Gardens

Penang Botanical Garden is one of the most peaceful place, you will find tourist and local enjoying the scenery.

 It even has a trail covered in covered in cobbled stones, need to be careful as it is pretty slippery as you would have expected from a tropical forest. For trail lovers, this is nice short 500 to 600 meter trail going up and down a small hill.

A favorite garden for many Penangites to go for a morning walk/jog/hike. The only downside is that it could get a little crowded during weekend. Make sure you reach there before 7:30 am to get a good parking spot.

Albeit being a small garden with a jogging length of only around 1.9km per round, the garden is well kept and clean. People throng the place on weekends and you will see many people jogging around the park.

Parking is considerably easy to find since the turnover rate is quite high.
After the rain, A great place to stroll

Here you can see the last resting place for many of the people who helped create the great place of Penang, including the great man Sir Francis Light himself who come up with the idea of firing cannons full of gold coins into the impassable jungle to get people to cut it down to find the coins
Old but very artistic...
Our favorite head was of a white man who was supposedly murdered by a "band of Asian robbers". Colonialism at its finest.
there's a monthly cemetery guided tour conducted here on the last sunday of the month
Lovely and peaceful place, although rather sad as well (apparently 1/3 of the graves belong to people under 30).

Good service by the friendly sales promoter. We were able to try most of the cookies there before buying. And they were patient to give us recommendations on what to buy, not showing us "busuk" face while we were considering. There's a few freebies when reach a minimum spend. We left what we bought there and collect it when we finished shopping, which is very convenient for not carrying a big bag around.
Quite a good place to look for souvenir to bring back for relatives and friends to try n eat those local delight from Penang.

Great hospitality. The shopkeeper let us try all of the goods sold before buying, informing any promotions and serve us patiently when we were still deciding which to buy. The durian ice cream is authentic and use real durian instead of essence with less cream compared to other durian ice cream i've tried at malay.
Great service, huge variety.
All is good
Good prices, cool eventhough outside. Only half the food shops open though. Tasted from 2 only average taste.

Variety of local Penang food and delicacies available here. However, this is known as a tourist spot. Ask some locals where to get good food around Georgetown and I'm sure they would be able to tell you. Personally, the food here is just normal to me.
Food court getting real expensive but with piss poor quality food. Not recommended.
The outstanding food varieties here is the Laksa n char koay teow. The ice kacang since the the vendor take over is useless. Expensive n ingredients not fresh
various type of hawker food, suitable for tourist but not local people.

Delicious Indian food. Clean place to eat with an incredible taste. The service is pretty good and the portions are average size. The whole banana leaf thing is fun and a must try but kind of a touristy things. I would get other things next time. Now that we've done the banana leaf experience!

Good spacious place.

Supply is so slow.

Food is good and tasty.

Need to improve the speed of customer handling....

I gave 3 star. In terms of food, it was delicious and they served fast. And they served banana leaf which we like it. But in terms of waiter service, the first waiter has no patient to wait for us to decide which food we wanted to eat. Then he asked his friend to serve us. This is not the way. We paid for service charge you know? It is not FREE. So why treated us in that way?
Extremely expensive price for very simple food. Not recommended at all

Huge menu of South Indian delicacies, including thosai, banana leaf rice and Tandoori chicken. Relatively inexpensive. 
Ample & free parking. Plenty of seating space in an open air area. Alternatively there's air conditioned seating in a small building by the side of the main area. 
Try their mutton masala. Wonderful !

Good selection of South Indian cuisines / menus. Menus prepared instantly and with fresh ingredients. Cooks are well experts in their preparations. Overall the restaurant is clean and waiters are polite and accommodating.  The space are limited, so you got to be quick especially during rush hours. So plan your visit accordingly.
Great indian banana leaf style, most delicious were the ghee masala dosa. We ate here a number if times because we like dosa and these were really good.
One of our most memorable and enjoyable meals in Malaysia. Excellent dosas, no frills, and definitely a locals spot.
Amazing food. Easy to order! They ask a few questions and start bringing you food right away!
Go there! Amazing Indian banana leave restaurant. Sit down, be served and enjoy. Food is delicious, price is fair, staff was super friendly. I strongly recommend this restaurant!
Took a bit of finding but an interesting place when you get there. It's on the second floor overlooking the major road junction.  A decent menu at very reasonable prices.  It's worth a visit.
Good and reasonably priced food. Our regular destination for western food. Friendly and pleasant service.

Nice relax environment. Good very 平民价。waiter and waitress are very friendly with a smile always.
Keep it up.
Great service. Attentive boss. Great food and reasonably priced.

A very nice restaurant on the second floor of the shopping complex. About seven selections for lunch featuring local cuisine in the 18 Ringett range ($4.50); dinner runs in the 25 Ringett range ($6.25). Salads, soups and desert are available. A variety of coffees, teas, smoothies, soft drinks and beer are offered.

A Sunday roast beef dinner with all the trimmings is featured for 40 Ringett ($10.00). The food is excellent. Both indoor and outdoor seating available.

Service good, food mostly okay only, deep fried squid was delicious - batter crispy & the squid tender. There are dance performances.Toilets clean. Easily accessible to wheelchair. Has parking space but you have to pay.

Two stars, instead of one, for the views. The beachfront perfectly oriented views are amazing; mountain backdrop combined with ocean and sand = amazing!
The food and beer was terrible. 
The mango salad tasted like onions and burnt beef, and the beer was room temperature. How do you mess up beer?
The staff was slow and lethargic too. As I walked in, the receptionist looked at me and then looked back down at her phone. 
Many other people had decent reviews, however mine was not even close. 

Plenty of other, better, options only a one night it’d walk away.
Expensive. Food taste nothing to shout about. On top of the expensive food, they add up 10% service charge making the total bill not worth the experience. Will not visit the place again.

Get good variety of food, especially sea food. A number of aquariums containing different variety of fish, all on the menu also. Evening they performed an Eastern song and dance routine. Then guests were invited to participate. An entertaining end to an enjoyable meal.

beautiful shoreline beach beside the golden thai restoran.beach is very clean and some water sports right in front makes it happening and very interesting to watch while dining and enjoying the strong sea breeze.food taste was average. 1 whole of  medium size 'kam hiong ' crab , a medium size kailan vege, 1 jug of water with one sliced lemon in it , 1 fresh orange juice and 1 medium size of fried rice totalling RM239.00 included 15% surcharged.
